raw_text:
Ultra fast wi-fi nears completion
 
 Ultra high speed wi-fi connections moved closer to reality on Thursday when Intel said it would list standards for the technology later this year.
 
 Intel is developing ultra-wideband technology (UWB) which would allow fast data transfer but with low power needs. UWB is tipped to be used for wireless transfer of video in the home or office and for use in wireless USB devices which need low power consumption. A rival UWB standard is being developed by Motorola and chip firm Freescale. At the mobile phone conference 3GSM in Cannes last month Samsung demonstrated a phone using UWB technology from Freescale.
 
 At a press conference on Thursday Intel announced that two UWB groups, WiMedia Alliance and Multi-band OFDM alliance had merged to support the technology. UWB makes it possible to stream huge amounts of data through the air over short distances. One of the more likely uses of UWB is to make it possible to send DVD quality video images wirelessly to TV screens or to let people beam music to media players around their home.
 
 The technology has the potential to transmit hundreds of megabits of data per second. "Consumer electronics companies want UWB to replace cables and simplify set-up," Jeff Ravencraft, technology strategist at Intel and chairman of the Wireless USB Promoter Group, told technology site ZDNet. "Thirty percent of consumer electronics returns are because the consumer couldn't set up the equipment." The first products using UWB technology from Intel are due to hit the market later this year. Initially they will be products using wireless USB 2.0 connections. UWB could also be used to create so-called Personal Area Networks that let a person's gadgets quickly and easily swap data amongst themselves. The technology works over a range up to 10 metres and uses billions of short radio pulses every second to carry data. Intel says the benefit of UWB is that it does not interfere with other wi-fi technologies already in use such as wi-fi, wimax and mobile phone networks.
llama3.2:1b: Ultra-fast Wi-Fi standards are moving closer to completion after Intel announced plans to list standards later this year.
Intel is developing ultra-wideband technology (UWB) for wireless data transfer that can transmit high amounts of data over short distances without power consumption.

The technology has the potential to enable:

* Streaming huge amounts of data wirelessly
* Beaming music and video to media players around homes

UWB's benefits include:
* Simplifying setup for consumer electronics
* Reducing returns due to failed set-up attempts
llama3.2:3b: Intel announces plans for ultra-wideband technology (UWB) which could enable fast wireless data transfer with low power needs, potentially used for streaming video and wireless USB devices; two UWB groups merge to support the standard; initial products using UWB technology from Intel expected later this year.
gemma2:2b: Intel will release standards for ultra-wideband (UWB) technology later this year.
This technology can provide high-speed wireless data transfer over short distances and is expected to replace cables in consumer electronics.
UWB can be used for streaming video, wireless USB devices, and Personal Area Networks.
The first UWB products are anticipated to launch later this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Intel announced plans to develop ultra-wideband technology (UWB), which allows fast data transfer but with low power needs.
UWB technology could be used for wireless video transmission, wireless USB devices, DVD quality video images, or Personal Area Networks.
The technology makes it possible to transmit hundreds of megabits per second over short distances.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Intel plans to list standards for ultra-wideband (UWB) technology later this year, which would allow fast data transfer with low power needs.
UWB has potential applications including wireless video transfers, wireless USB devices, and personal area networking.
Intel expects its first products using UWB technology from partners Motorola and Freescale to hit the market in 2015, supporting simpler setup for consumer electronics companies.
qwen2.5:3b: Ultra fast Wi-Fi nears completion as Intel announced standards for Ultra Wideband (UWB) technology, set to be available later this year.

Developed by Intel alongside Motorola and Freescale, UWB aims to provide high-speed data transfer with low power consumption, suitable for home or office wireless video transfer and low-power USB devices.
Samsung demonstrated a UWB-enabled phone at the 3GSM conference.
Two UWB groups merged to support the technology, which could transmit up to hundreds of megabits per second.
Intel predicts UWB replacing cables and simplifying electronics setup, with initial products expected in late 2010 for wireless USB 2.0 connections.
UWB can create Personal Area Networks for gadget data exchange over a 10-meter range without interfering with existing Wi-Fi technologies like WiMAX or mobile networks.
opencoder:1.5b:
Ultra fast wireless connection nearing completion

The development of ultra-wideband (UWB) technology has been praised for its potential to offer fast data transfer capabilities without the need for power infrastructure that traditional wireless technology often requires.
It is anticipated to be used extensively in areas like home or office communication, as well as in USB devices requiring low power consumption.
The UWB standard is expected to form the foundation for 3GSM networks in the Cannes symposium and will play a crucial role in future mobile device usage.
Intel has also announced that they are working with Motorola and other chip firms to develop their own UWB standards, known as Multi-band OFDM (OFDM) or Multi-Channel UWB.
The merger with the WiMedia Alliance and the Multi-band OFDM alliance will enable UWB to support the technology in a more sophisticated and efficient manner.
UWB promises high-speed data transfer rates of up to hundreds of megabits per second, indicating that it can facilitate high-resolution video streaming or wireless music playing.
With this technology, consumer electronics companies are eager to leverage the convenience of setting up their equipment without the need for traditional cables and set-up procedures.
The first products from Intel reaching the market are expected in the coming months.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Ultra-wideband technology is approaching near completion as it offers faster data transfer with lower power needs.
Intel has announced listing standards for their UWB (ultra-wideband) technology, which is expected to be used in home and office environments.
The technology uses short radio pulses every second to transmit large amounts of data over short distances, such as video or music streaming.
Two UWB groups, WiMedia Alliance and the Multi-band OFDM alliance, have merged for support.
Samsung is using UWB from Freescale for their products.
Consumer electronics companies aim to replace cables and streamline setup, with 30% sales attributed to ease of setup.
UWB could send high-quality videos wirelessly and create personal area networks within 10 meters, potentially offering a simpler alternative to traditional wired connections.
tinyllama:1.1b: Intel has announced that the Wi-Fi Alliance and Multi-band OFDM Alliance have merged to support Ultra High Speed Wireless Network (UHF) technology.

This high speed wireless technology enables fast data transfer in the home or office, with low power needs, allowing for wireless streaming of video images over short distances or sharing of large amounts of data over short distances.
The potential applications for this technology include the creation of personal area networks that use UWB technology for easy and quick exchange of data amongst devices.
Intel has announced that the first products using UHF technology will be released later this year, with initial versions featuring wireless USB 2.0 connections due to hit the market by early 2010.

Ultra high-speed wireless networking is expected to revolutionize the mobile industry and consumer electronics, providing quicker connectivity, improved reliability and increased convenience for consumers.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Ultra high speed wireless internet technology, often referred to as ultra-wideband (UWB) technology, has been on the horizon for quite some time but has made substantial strides towards completion recently.
Intel, a leading tech company, has announced that they are now planning to list specifications for UWB technology this year.

This milestone demonstrates an increasing interest in wireless data transfer and aims to revolutionize consumer electronics, making it possible for them to connect with each other over short distances and even share large files wirelessly.
One of the key factors that drive the potential success of UWB technology is its compatibility with existing wi-fi networks and devices.

UWB also uses less power than current wireless technologies, allowing it to be used in a variety of applications such as sending high-resolution video clips over short distances, or even connecting multiple devices wirelessly from the same source.

Intel's collaboration with Freescale on the development of UWB technology has been an exciting step forward for wireless communication and has laid the foundation for future developments in this area.
With the combination of these companies, it is likely that we will see more innovative uses of UWB for wireless data transfer, entertainment, and even communication across long distances.

As with other technologies, consumer electronics companies are keen to adopt UWB technology, as it not only promises faster data transmission but also makes it easier for them to upgrade their devices without having to invest in expensive cables or new hardware.
However, it is essential that all relevant parties come together and agree on a common standard for UWB technology.
Once this has been achieved, the possibilities for wireless communication will be endless, and consumers will no doubt benefit from faster data transfer times and improved connectivity.
phi:2.7b: Intel announced the development of ultra-wideband (UWB) technology, which allows for fast data transfer over short distances using low power needs.
Two UWB groups merged to support this technology, and it has potential uses for wireless transfer of large amounts of data, including video in the home or office and wireless USB devices.
The first products using UWB are expected to be available later this year, initially as wireless USB 2.0.
UWB could also create Personal Area Networks that let gadgets quickly swap data amongst themselves without interference from other wi-fi technologies already in use.
orca-mini:3b: Ultrafast Wi-Fi technology developed by Intel is nearing completion.
The company has been working on a new standard called ultra-wideband (UWB) which allows for fast data transfer with low power consumption.
UWB technology could be used to wirelessly stream high-quality video from a smartphone or media player to a TV screen, or to simplify set-up when setting up electronic devices.
A rival group is also developing a UWB standard, but Intel has merged two groups to support the technology.
The first products using UWB technology from Intel are expected to hit the market later this year, initially using wireless USB 2.0 connections.
hermes3:3b: Intel develops UWB Wi-Fi standards, aiming for high-speed, low-power wireless connections for video streaming, media players, and personal area networks.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Intel is developing ultra-wideband (UWB) technology for fast and low-power wireless data transfer, with potential uses including video streaming and wireless USB devices.
Two UWB groups, WiMedia Alliance and Multi-band OFDM alliance, have merged to support the technology.
Intel plans to release its first products using UWB later this year, initially focusing on wireless USB connections.
The benefit of UWB is its ability to transmit data without interfering with other wireless technologies like Wi-Fi, WiMax, and mobile networks.

UWB is expected to be used for streaming video, wireless USB devices, and personal area networks.
Intel announced that two UWB groups, WiMedia Alliance and Multi-band OFDM Alliance, have merged to support the technology.
Rival UWB technology is being developed by Motorola and Freescale, with Samsung demonstrating a UWB-enabled phone.
UWB can transmit hundreds of megabits per second over short distances and aims to replace cables for consumer electronics.
Intel's first UWB products, featuring wireless USB 2.0, are expected later this year.
The technology does not interfere with existing wireless networks like Wi-Fi and mobile networks.
stablelm2:1.6b: Intel announces plans for ultra wideband (UWB) technology, which would enable fast wireless data transfer without interference with existing WiFi and cellular network technologies.
UWB is expected to be used for video streaming, wireless USB devices, and personal area networks.
The two leading UWB groups, WiMedia Alliance and Multi-band OFDM alliance, have merged to support the technology's development.
Intel expects to release first products utilizing UWB in 2010, initially as wireless USB 2.0 connections but potentially expanding to Personal Area Networks (PANs) for sharing data between devices.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Intel has announced it will soon release standards for ultra high-speed wireless technology called Ultra Wideband (UWB).
This technology, developed by Intel, enables rapid data transfer with minimal power consumption.
Key uses include streaming DVD-quality video to TVs or wirelessly playing music on media players within a 10-meter range.
The first products integrating UWB will likely be wireless USB 2.0 devices.
UWB's compatibility with existing Wi-Fi, WiMax, and mobile networks is assured, as it doesn't interfere with them.
Competing UWB standards are being developed by Motorola and Freescale, with Samsung showcasing a UWB phone at the 3GSM conference.
Intel expects this technology to reduce consumer electronics returns due to setup issues and simplify cable-free device connections.
